abstract.text: This property can be used to override the priming and remainder information in an audio file, and also to retrieve the current priming and remainder frames information for an extended audio file object. If the underlying file type does not provide packet table information, attempting to get the value of this property returns an error.

inlineContent.text: By setting this property with a nonnegative number (which may be the value
), you override the corresponding settings for the values contained in the file. If you use a value of
for either the priming or remainder frames, the extended audio file object uses the corresponding value stored in the file.
Retrieving the value of this property always retrieves the value the extended audio file object is using, whether derived from the file or from your override.
To determine the value in the file, use the
When the property is set, only the remaining and priming values are used. Set the

struct to zero. For example, a file encoded using AAC may have 2112 samples of priming at the start of the file and a remainder of 823 samples at the end. When an extended audio file object returns decoded samples to you, it trims off the
at the start of the file, and trims off the
at the end. It gets these numbers initially from the file. A common use case for overriding this would be to set the priming and remainder samples to

. In this example, you would retrieve an additional 2112 samples of silence from the start of the file and 823 samples of silence at the end of the file (silence, because the encoders use silence to pad out these priming and remainder samples).

abstract.text: Record or play audio, convert formats, parse audio streams, and configure your audio session.
Contains information about the number of valid frames in a file and where they begin and end.
An audio file object property identifier.
Read or write a variety of audio data to or from disk or a memory buffer.
Gets or sets an audio file packet table information structure for its supporting file types. When setting the structure, the sum of the values of the
and
fields must be the same as the total number of frames in all packets. If not, a
is returned. To ensure this result, get the value of the property and make sure the sum of the three values you set has the same sum as the three values you got.
The audio converter object associated with the extended audio file object, if a converter is associated.
The audio file object associated with the extended audio file object.
The audio channel layout for your application.
The audio stream format for your application.
Your application audio data format’s maximum packet size, in bytes. Value is a read-only
The manufacturer of the codec to be used by the extended audio file object. Value is a read/write
The configuration of the extended audio file object’s associated audio converter, as specified by the
property. Value is a read/write
object.
A file’s channel layout.
A file’s data format.
The associated audio file’s length in sample frames. Value is an
. For a PCM file, the value is read/write. For a non-PCM file, the value is read-only.
The file data format’s maximum packet size, in bytes. Value is a read-only
An audio data buffer. Value is a read/write
value.
The size of the buffer that the extended audio file object’s associated audio converter uses to read or write the associated audio file. Value is a read/write

This property can be used to override the priming and remainder information in an audio file, and also to retrieve the current priming and remainder frames information for an extended audio file object. If the underlying file type does not provide packet table information, attempting to get the value of this property returns an error.
